name: dependency-cruiser-ts
description: Generates a dependency graph from a JavaScript or TypeScript file

dependency-cruiser-ts.analysis.tsConfigP.description: Glob pattern for the file name of the tsconfig file. The extension will look for files matching this pattern in the workspace folder of the analyzed file. If multiple matching files are found, you will be prompted to pick one.

dependency-cruiser-ts.analysis.collapseP.markdownDescription:
Regular expression used to collapse parts of the graph. For example, if your project imports `@foo/bar/one.js`, `@foo/bar/two.js` and `@foo/qux/three.js` :
- `node_modules/(@[^/]+/[^/]+|[^/]+)` will collapse the `node_modules` part of the graph into two nodes: `@foo/bar` and `@foo/qux`
- `node_modules/[^/]+` will collapse the `node_modules` part of the graph into one node: `@foo`

dependency-cruiser-ts.analysis.includeOn.markdownDescription:
Regular expression that restricts the dependency analysis to files that match it. Can be combined with the `exclude` option. For example:
- `^src/` will ignore imports from outside of the `src` folder.

dependency-cruiser-ts.analysis.exclude.markdownDescription:
Regular expression that excludes the files that match it from the dependency analysis. Can be combined with the `includeOnly` option. For example:
- `^node_modules/` will ignore imports from inside of the `node_modules` folder.

dependency-cruiser-ts.graph.theme.description: Visual theme used in the graph.

dependency-cruiser-ts.graph.colorScheme.description: Color scheme (light or dark) used in the graph.

dependency-cruiser-ts.graph.linesShape.description: Controls the shape of the lines between nodes.
enumDescriptions: Lines will be curved and avoid other nodes
Lines will be curved an go through other nodes
Lines will be straight and make right angles
Lines will move in multiple successive straight paths

dependency-cruiser-ts.graph.direction.description: Direction of the graph, i.e. the direction from a node A to the nodes of the modules imported by A.
enumDescriptions: If a module A imports a module B, then B will be drawn to the right of A
If a module A imports a module B, then B will be drawn to the bottom of A
If a module A imports a module B, then B will be drawn to the left of A
If a module A imports a module B, then B will be drawn to the top of A

scripts.vscode:prepublish: npm run copy && npm run compile
scripts.pretest: npm run compile && npm run lint
